course.subject: MARK
course.name: Marketing Management
course.description: Introduction to marketing from the perspective of the decision-maker; controllable variables (product, price, promotion and distribution), uncontrollable variables (competition, law, society, technology, and economy), consumer behavior and marketing research.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Heaven for extroverts. Hell for introverts.üòû
reviews.comment_content:
The course provides a basic but very well-structured framework of the marketing process, which is particularly useful not only for students aiming to be marketing professionals, but also anyone who wanna market himself when finding a job, selling his idea, etc.

Topics included:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Introduction to Marketing Management
2Ô∏è‚É£ Marketing Research
3Ô∏è‚É£ Consumer Buyer Behavior
      üî∂ Consumer Characteristics
      üî∂ Buyer Decision Process
4Ô∏è‚É£ Segmenting, Targeting, and Positioning
      üî∂ Differentiation and Segmenting
      üî∂ Value Proposition - Targeting and Positioning
5Ô∏è‚É£ 4P's
      üî∂ Branding Strategy
      üî∂ Pricing Strategy
      üî∂ Marketing Channels
      üî∂ Promotion
6Ô∏è‚É£ Marketing Ethics and Social Responsibility

The last lecture on ethics and social responsibility was especially rewarding. She introduced 'storydoing' and how enterprises nowadays could leverage the social power of 'storydoing', instead of 'storytelling', to increase the social impact their promotional campaign created. She even further covered how to become an influential and an inspiring person, by addressing the 'why' question first rather than the 'what' question - a 'why' question is the value proposition that brings about values to customers, whereas a 'what' question is the products or the services we deliver to the customers. This is explained by our intrinsic tendency to be influenced by emotions first, rather than rational thinking.

This is one of the most useful and inspiring courses I've ever taken in UST.
reviews.comment_teaching: PUIG is indeed the weirdest professor I've ever seen, but she is hell passionate. Even though she's got the worst accent, the most exceptional style of clothing, a not-so-good body shape, whatever... I still LOVED her teaching. I felt like she was the mother of every single student. She cared about every one of us, fully understood our characters, and tried to help us learn in a way we didn't even notice. I've changed so much under her teaching that I feel like I've transformed into another person.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading on a pro-rata basis, i.e. every student is my competitor. The professor herself hated it a lot, but she had to follow the school regulation.

From the moment I realized my competitors are CRAZILY capable - QFIN, Dual-degree students are not even worth mentioning. We've got curve wreckers from mainland China who've stayed in the US for quite a bit of time, or who've taken 60 credits in merely 1 year, a WBB student (the first time I've ever met one, tbh), exchange students from Ivy Leagues, public speaking champions, and even a 32-year-old lawyer who works in a professional law firm (DAMN it!!! Why would she ever go to take a marketing course in UST lol). Under such fierce competition, with my cr*ppy English speaking and presentation skills, and also because I'm such an introvert and I dared not speak in front of the whole class, I got a sh!tty grade at the end.

Coursework weighting:
üìÇ In-class participation - 33%
      üè´ Class attendance - 13%
      üí¨ In-class activities - 20%
üìÇ Group project - 32%
      ‚úèÔ∏è Marketing plan (write-up) - 13%
      üí¨ Marketing plan (presentation) - 7%
      ‚úèÔ∏è Case analysis - 12%
‚úèÔ∏è Final quiz - 35%

Dunno how marks were given towards in-class activities. Maybe this is all about impression. I wonder if the professor knew my Chinese name?! This course is heavily weighted towards class participation and projects. The professor even tends to deliberately increase the deviation of our scores in these components to amplify the impact of these areas and tune down the impact of exams on our grades. For an inactive, taciturn, but exam-oriented person like me, this grading was obviously a headache. üòñ

Overall a very Western-styled grading that emphasizes the importance of projects over exams. Well, I understand that. It makes no sense for a marketing course to be heavily weighted towards exams, anyway. But at last I couldn't secure my grade even though I burrowed through the final quiz cuz my project parts were already all f**ked up.

In the projects our group was probably the one that encountered the most issues and problems - one group mate was not in Hong Kong for a total of 3 weeks (out of a course that lasted for only 5 weeks), having no choice but to leave everything behind to the rest of the group mates, and another group mate even 'disappeared' at the end. (WTF???) From a learning perspective, you should learn how to work with any person, yet if you consider your workload as well as your grade, you should choose your group mates carefully.

My performance on each component:
‚úèÔ∏è Case analysis - below mean
‚úèÔ∏èüí¨ Marketing plan - below mean
üè´ Class attendance - full marks
üí¨ In-class activities - not shown, but 100% sure mine was f**ked up
‚úèÔ∏è Final quiz - above mean

Final grade: B+

I dunno how come I only got 6/12 in the case analysis. I didn't expect this part to be f**ked up like this when my group mates all thought we had submitted something normal... (???) And the professor said all our marketing plans in the whole class deserved an A-range, but I only got 13/20. Dunno what happened at the end. Maybe because of the peer evaluation?

Tears~ üò≠üò≠üò≠

My warning - DON'T take this course in summer. Students taking this course in summer are usually really into this course and hence the competition will be extremely fierce. Well, I learned a lot from my peers tho, but if you're taking it for the grade, then think twice before registering for a summer class.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is heavily weighted towards class participation and projects. You can thus imagine how much time I had to devote in this course - full attendance in class is mandatory and is merely basic.

The heaviest workload is surely the marketing plan - every group had to go from the very beginning to develop an idea, go through the whole marketing process, and present the whole idea in front of the whole class. This is demanding for an introductory course, especially in summer, when the course typically only lasts for 5 weeks.

The case analysis is another piece of sh!t - our case was an extract from an MBA year-2 course in Harvard business school. Ewwww I didn't understand fuck about the case as the case is on Beyonc√©, and I was a total music noob, so you can imagine how much effort I had to put in to sort things out and understand what the heck was going on. (But after I've got the whole idea I realized how brilliant her marketing strategy was. She did promotion in a way as if there was no promotion, and by doing so she deliberately created media speculation. Beyonc√©'s simply a marketing genius!!!)

Anyway, heavy workload brings about good learning process. I did learn a lot from it, so I shouldn't have complained.

reviews.author: Stetanjung
reviews.title: Bad English accent
reviews.comment_content: I would say that the content is actually pretty interesting. She divided the whole class into three parts, which are 3C, STP, and 4P (you'll know what they are when you take this class). Pretty basic theories; the focus is mainly about the role of marketing strategy in the organizations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am not being subjective, but Prof. Yang's English is kinda bad. It was quite difficult to understand what she meant for the whole thing, and the class was kinda boring. She was new, though, so maybe she was still adjusting at that time. She couldn't explain the whole thing clearly, and she was just repeating the presentations.

She was pretty nice, though...

reviews.comment_workload:
Typical marketing class.

A lot of meetings, presentations, quizzes and projects.

Since you can choose your own mates, it would actually ease your workload, unless you're kind of unlucky guy who gets terrible mates. If you know your mates better, the workload will be pretty low, being the projects divide evenly. You just have to focus on the quizzes, since they comprise to half of your total grades, and they are your personal performances, so those you can work harder.

reviews.author: bcc
reviews.title: Don't reg Christine Kim
reviews.comment_content:
Content taught in short would be 3Cs STP 4Ps.
Honestly speaking the contents are a little bit crappy (e.g. pricing at $3.99 is better than $4.00), but the concepts and abbreviations are actually used in real life and I see them in reports during my internships so I guess it's not completely useless (?)

Just study (aka memorize) everything and you'll be alright
reviews.comment_teaching:
Long story short as my semester was a zoom semester we had online quizzes, one time I forgot to fill in the honor code and she not only voided my quiz but sent me a long-ass email explaining "how wrong I was" and how "I don't care about the course", I mean it's my bad that I'm careless but is a 641 word email (yes I counted) really necessary ffs.

To be fair she does engage students in her lectures but her attitude is just unbearable, she interrupts student's answers and always acts like she's morally superior.

If you want a nice professor I don't care who you reg just don't do her.
reviews.comment_grading:
In one word - nontransparent.

Best 2 out of 3 quizzes (27% each)
Group project report (23%)
Group project presentation (10%)
In-class exercise (10%)
Research participation (3%)
Class participation (+/- 10%)

My 2 quizzes (yes cuz she voided one): 22.5/27 & 24/30
(they are both slightly above mean)
Group project report: 19/23
Group project presentation: 9/10
(also slightly above mean for both)
Research: 3/3
Grade: B

I'd say i didn't do too bad for in-class exercises and I did participate in class, it's not even sure if she uses absolute grading or curved (if it's absolute grading then mean is somewhere around C+) so I have no idea how my B was calculated, I see my friends doing more work and better projects and getting B- so I wanna know what's up with her too.

But anyways cuz I had beef with her so I expected a shit grade anyways.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy. the 3 quizzes are spread out across the semester so u gotta constantly revise (if you want a good grade), but the project makes it more difficult cuz you gotta collab with your project-mates to do a marketing plan (ppt + presentation + report), if your groupmates arent good then congrats you'll have to do everything + get a bad grade afterwards (cuz your proj will probs turn out to be a lil crappy).

Lastly the attendance is stressful as I'm in a class with a lot of active students so it's hard to get Christine to notice you.

reviews.author: LapisDoughnut
reviews.title: Bye Bye GPA
reviews.comment_content:
You can learn about the basics of marketing framework in this course.
3C: Customer, Company, Competitor
STP: Segmentation, Targeting, Positioning
4P: Product, Promotion, Place, Price

Quite easy to understand these from the slides.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Really, Wenbo is not a bad prof *if* we only count his teaching.

It would be fun to hear him talking and also he tries to use different  entertaining advertisements to be examples.

Class time always flies, not only it is quite fun to learn but also Wenbo ends quickly for some lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
The distribution of marks:
50% Quizzes with 25% each (Best 2 out of 3 counted)
37% Final Group Project Report (27% Report 10%)
3% Research Credit
10% In-Class Group Case Discussion
+/-10% Participation

Wenbo also promised he would also give more As and be more fair for the distribution in the hope of "better results".
In the end? Bruh.
Scored 95/100, 93/103 and 90/100 for the 3 quizzes (Mean 93/100, around 88/103 and 7X/100)
My result? C+. I was expecting a B range but whatever.

The results of project are not disclosed so I don't know my performance.
Participation is quite hard to get, because it was always the same bunch of extrovert guys rushing to answer and there is not really many questions to be answered. (You can even recognize their voices even you switched to other sites or not focusing on lessons) I think I just managed to answer for 1 to 2 times but anyway C+. Right. C+.

I did learn many useful knowledge, in exchange of a low grade. Sayonara GPA.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not that hard to finish the workload
3 quizzes in overall which is easy, 3 Marking research credit and a group report. There is also 1 case study discussion in which you will have to elaborate one question assigned to your group.

For the quizzes, it is quite straightforward so it is just like Wenbo suggested "you just need around one hour to prepare every quizzes." Being familiar with the cases and slides discussed and taking a quick look in the practice questions, you will be fine for a high mark in the 50%.

reviews.author: mushroom
reviews.comment_content: excellent contents, will definitely learn a lot and appreciate the course
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is impeccable. Wenbo put so much energy and enthusiasm in education. The course is fun, and also he gives some time to take a break or let us leave early. It is so lovely to be in his class that he is humorous, and the topics are well organized. He even tries to make the contents more attractive by taking examples of students' favorite companies in discussions.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fine. Didn't speak up in class, 1.2 sd above mean in the quiz, got b+. Don't know the project score, though. But it's okay for me. It is, of course, better to get involved in the class to let him remember you. There is a +/-10% grade for participation.
reviews.comment_workload: He emphasizes before quizzes that we spend only 1 hour on the exams. However, it is not true lol. Participate in every class and listen to the discussions (important!!), don't need to take notes, and spend 3 hours preparing for the quiz! Group project also is time-consuming, gotta have good plans.

reviews.author: rubbishstudent
reviews.title: do not choose her
reviews.comment_content: The content is interesting as it talks about advertisements, some basic marketing concepts with lots of examples.
reviews.comment_teaching:
HELL.
You have no idea what she is talking in her class as she is just saying what she likes. I attended all the classes just to let her remember me but not for learning. I just learn all the knowledge through reading textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
NONREASONABLE.
The quiz mean is lower than other marketing professor as she does not really talk much about the content and expect us to read the book by ourselves. But the questions from the quiz was copied from other professors and do not match with what is mentioned in the textbook.
There is 10% participation mark , 1% is equivalent to 1 course grade. My friend and I attend all the lessons, but our marks deviate by 4 marks , we have no idea how she gives out the mark.
If you are a local student, do not reg this professor, seriously.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much, she gave us enough time for discussion during class.

reviews.comment_content:
Basic marketing concepts.
4Ps
a few chapters from the textbook
reviews.comment_teaching:
She is not teaching at all lol.
She is blowing water in class, sharing what happened to her daily life.
She is really bad at teaching, she dun reli know how to teach.
She is the wort teacher i met in HKUST so far

She want people to talk more and she really loves foreigners, if you were from the US, you will definitely get A range.
The grade really depends on how much she likes you and she loves foreigners.
She likes people to give sh*t to her, so remember to talk with her more if you want a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 quizzes and will count all quizzes unlike other professors.
group project and presentation, the group project is not difficult.

reviews.author: Rex J
reviews.title: Don't choose Kim
reviews.comment_content:
Basic introduction of the marketing concept(3C,STP,4P)
3C: Consumer, Company, Competition.
STP: Segmentation, targeting, positioning
4P: Promotion, product, price, place.
The structure of this course is quite clear and after finish one section, you will have a quiz. Thus, there are three quizzes and if you remember all the notes and \ example she mentioned, you will be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think she can explain the concept well cause she will use lots of examples and her own experience to explain it.
However, her attitude is no good. if you have a good impression in her mind, you can survive better.
reviews.comment_grading:
Best 2 out of 3 quizzes(54%)
Group project report (23%)
Group project presentation (10%)
In-class exercise (10%)
Research participation (3%)
Class participation (+/- 10%)

Just try your best to do better in the quizzes cause it can save your life!!!!
For the group project, just pray to have good group mates cause you will assign randomly to a group and Kim like your group idea.
And the class participation, you can just ignore it. if you are a toxic guy like me, you will get 0 in this part. But don't worry cause most of the students will also get this mark if you aren't outstanding in the class.
Overall, my quizzes(above 1s.d), group project and presentation(lowest in our section).
Finally, B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy. Because you will have 3 quizzes and 1 project. Usually, if you are targeting a good grade in the quizzes, you need to study around 2 days before the quizzes. And the project is the most annoying one cause you need to spend whole sem to finish it and if you don't have a good teammate, it is horrible.
Luckily this course doesn't have Final:)

reviews.author: Wolfheart
reviews.title: Decent introductory course on various marketing theories
reviews.comment_content:
See "Course Syllabus" attachment for lessons.

Exams are non-cumulative and to be honest, the content isn't so bad. Quizzes consist of 25 multiple choice questions worth 4 points each, that require choosing ALL of the correct answers (e.g. it can be A/B/D from a set of A/B/C/D/E). Take note that questions with "which of the following" could indicate that only one of the given choices is correct, although this was not explicitly made clear.

The final project is about a product that you'd like to bring to market, and an application of all the marketing concepts. It is a groupwork with 5-6 people at RANDOM so pray that you get good groupmates.

There is a lot of information but it's not difficult to remember since it intuitively makes sense and as the content is about fundamentals, it is more practical. Overall, an enjoyable course, and more so if conducted physically.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is really friendly and tries to keep the class jolly and chill. She offers reasonable feedback during consultation periods for the final project. If you have any questions for quizzes, she is also responsive.

Didn't really interact much with T.A. Pauline, but she can give statistics for breakdown in the final grade if you send her an e-mail. Since this semester was online, paper-viewing was not allowed and instead, the alternative was you can ask her about items you were unsure of in the quiz. If you successfully identify the question you got wrong in, she'll tell you the correct answer; otherwise, she'll say that you got the item correct. The quiz-viewing scheme was absolute BS because how and why will you even remember the question. Attended once and never again.
reviews.comment_grading:
Components:
[25%+30%] Quizzes - best 2 of 3
[27%] Final Project Report
[15%] Final Project Presentation
[3%] Research Credit - 1% per marketing study
[+/- 10%] Class Participation

My Scores:
Quiz 1: 80/100 (mean: 78, median: 80, max: 96, low: 44)
Quiz 2: 84/100 (mean: 74.6, sd: 13.4, max: 100, low: 40)
Quiz 3: 84/100 (mean: 77, sd: 16.8, max: 100, low: 32)
Presentation - 12.35/15 (mean: 12.25754717, sd:
0.557233414, max: 13.15, min: 11.3)
Report: 25/27 (mean: 23.40566038, sd: 1.508018204, min: 20.5, max: 26)
Credit:  3/3
Participation: +4%

In aggregate, scored 90.55% for the course, which is equivalent to an A. No idea how that happened when barely anything was even 1 sd above, especially with quizzes being the 55% majority. Got terrible groupmates and wrote a peer evaluation ranting about it, so that could've played a role. Recited around 4-5 times throughout the semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
Concepts for the quiz aren't difficult. You could survive by studying on the night before; however, during the quiz itself, there is slight time pressure (30mins for 25 questions) and trickiness (choosing multiple correct answers). Exams are close-book but with UST's wonderful anti-cheating systems in place (or lack thereof!), highly doubt it. Statistics were similar to previous years though, so trickiness likely has more to do than with your knowledge or study effort.

Recitation for the 10% class participation was competitive, with up to 15/50 people in the class raising their hands for one question. Obviously, professor can't call everyone, but she does 3-5 people. Recitation opportunities become more infrequent with progression of the course, so try to recite early (e.g. barely any during topics for Quiz 3).

The final project, both report and presentation, was hard-carry for me. My group was full of uncooperative free-riders. Otherwise, the project would have been a fun.

reviews.author: Polaris
reviews.title: LIAR
reviews.comment_content:
Marketing Framework
3Cs, 4Ps, STP
3C: customer, company, competitor
4P: product, promotion, place, price
STP: segmentation, targeting, positioning

things such as strategies that could differentiate your products from others', how to set your price given competitors' reactions. He incorporates some daily technology into his lecture, making his lesson less boring. Big data stuff was also mentioned

Project: develop a marketing plan for a new product or an existing product.

Participation: highly emphasized, in-class case studies (3 of them) required.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Frankly, he is a funny guy and you will have many things to laugh at during his lesson.
High openness. He always says "there is no right/wrong answers", well when you try to answer or raise suggestions, he will start saying "but......".
reviews.comment_grading:
At the very beginning, he gave us the statistic of his grading in Spring 2013, showing how 'lenient' or 'fair' he distributed the grade. HOWEVER, among the 5 professors, he is the one who gave the most 'C's. Folks, dodge him if you want to get a desirable grade.

Note: there are multiple answers possible in those MC quizzes. Be very cautious. (You hv to blacken A and B on your answer sheet if both are true)

Quiz 1: 20/25
Quiz 2: 21/25
Quiz 3: 20/25
Team Project: N/A
Participation: N/A
Research credit: 3/3
GRADE: C+
reviews.comment_workload:
FREE-RIDERS EVERYFUCKINGWHERE.
there are only like 3 to 4 of us who did the thing. Well depends on how's your teammates' quality.

Quizzes are not particularly difficult, but make sure you score high to secure your C-range. LOL.

You have to prepare the case study that he distribute which matters to your participation.

reviews.author: Law~
reviews.title: Good Professor who teaches MARK2120 quite mediocrely
reviews.comment_content:
MARK2120 covers fundamental marketing concepts - 3C (Consumer, Company, Competition); STP (Segmentation, Positioning and Segmentation); 4P (Price, Product, Place, Promotion)

Every Professor covers similar concepts so it is almost the same among different sections in terms of concepts and intended learning outcomes. Therefore, the point that creates variation among sections would be
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am NEUTRAL to her teaching after all. Unfortunately, according to the grading scale in HKUST (executed by her and the ARRO), she would receive a C (well that's pretty reflect students' fates in UST!)

She hopes to make the class interactive but she clearly failed to do so.

(1) She bans mobile phone and laptop in class. The rationale was "to encourage the atmosphere of learning and interaction". We have reflected that appropriate use of electronic devices to facilitate learning should be encouraged in a questionnaire after 1/3 of the course but it was rejected

(2) She would ask questions to the class, but the questions are not in-depth enough to provoke thoughts or encourage further discussion. She would ask for something mentioned on PowerPoint Slides but seldom further the discussion on other forms of application. (But she mentioned that it is important to learn how to apply concepts)

(3) Therefore, under such great expectation fall from "her insights" and the "reality", many students do not show up in classes. In last regular classes (before presentation), only ~10 people are sitting at a 70-people classroom. I would like to express a little bit sympathy to KIM but honestly if she could release some of the regulations and think of some strategies to further stimulates discussion

(4) I would like to *compliment* KIM's as a person that she is nice, and she is a good business professor. Although her teaching is not excellent in MARK2120, I believe she is a good and inspirational "ËÄÅÁ¥∞" if you are pursuing in postgraduates studies. She had experiences in UCLA, INSEAD (well I suspect she should come from an extremely well-off from South Korea), and honestly her suggestions on your Projects, Research Observations Exercises are EXTREMELY beneficial, thought-provoking.

** FYI, she seems to be using unedited PowerPoint Slides to teach the classes from Professor Anirban back in 3/4 years ago
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair Grading

Quizzes take up 50% total in the course. There are three quizzes and the best 2 will be chosen to be counted. In my section, there are 25 questions in each quiz. Therefore, 1 MCQ = 1% of Course Grade. (This is not Kim's fault but the problem of MARK2120 Syllabus - Marketing should not turn out become a subject for recitation but application)

Kim's Quizzes are very difficult. Many minor concepts or concepts not mentioned or teaching content in classes will be assessed. And many options of MCQ are ambiguous. Prepare yourself with Mock Question Sets (by Pearson) would be very good because some (well actually quite a lot) questions would be adopted from there.

In Quiz 2, the questions were too difficult and many of students screwed that Professor and Teaching team need to add 3 points to each student. (There are MANY Ambiguous Questions - They want to make the questions more challenging and to differentiate good and bad students but it was totally failed)

6% goes to Research Participation. Remember to go to the appointed session
reviews.comment_workload:
No Comments on Workload. A typical UST Business Core Course Workload.

I would say MARK2120 is slightly heavier than MGMT2110 in terms of workload. (If we compare these two relatively ÂêπÊ∞¥Áßë together) since you probably need to complete an extra project and handle three quizzes in two months (which is very hectic)

reviews.author: Smashgod
reviews.comment_content:
Teaches the basic and fundamental marketing concepts, including STP, the 3Cs and 4Ps, and so on. Concepts are interesting and are demonstrated with the use of many real-life examples like advertisements and commercials.

Learning goals (extracted from course syllabus):
This course is designed to provide students with sufficient knowledge of marketing principles that will enable them to understand the role and operation of a marketing manager. It will also help them develop skills necessary to analyse marketing problems leading to the development of strategic and tactical plans consistent with analysis. Students in this course are expected to be able to:
1. Explain and discuss the general concepts about marketing management and the marketing process.
2. Identify and explain the key elements of a marketing plan.
3. Conduct a thorough analysis of the marketing environment and understand how environmental forces influence marketing decision-making.
4. Identify sources of marketing information necessary to develop a marketing plan.
5. Discuss consumer and buyer behavior models as they influence customer purchase decision-making.
6. Explain the concepts of segmentation, targeting and positioning as part of a comprehensive marketing plan.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Coral is an interactive and passionate professor. Every lesson she enthusiastically teaches marketing concepts while using ads and commercials to demonstrate them. She also encourages participation and tries to create more opportunities for students to ask and answer questions.

Pros:
1. Passionate and tries her best to clarify concepts
2. Casual and informal; can chill and loosen up in her lessons
3. Encourages raising questions: does not mind being cut off at all if someone wants to ask a question
4. Lenient in grading: I think impression and confidence are important in this course

Cons:
1. Usually late for class lol (~ 5 mins, but always ends on time), and sometimes absent (there was one time when the whole class was physically in the classroom while she taught on Zoom, and another time when she cancelled a 9 am class within an hour before the start)
2. Strong European accent: might be hard to hear what she is saying since the pronunciation may be off

Coral is well-known for encouraging participation and discussion, so many people think her classes are only for extroverts. How it works is that you need to ask or answer a meaningful question to get one participation mark, with 10 marks being the maximum (contributes to 10% of your total grade).

The TA, Jasmine Leung, is pretty incompetent and I am very disappointed. She is always not paying enough attention in lectures. She's in charge of uploading the slides to Canvas, but she always uploads the slides halfway through the class (so how am I supposed to take notes with my iPad?). She is also the one responsible for recording the participation marks but due to not paying enough attention in classes, I think she missed some participation records as well. Better ask her to confirm your participation every time after the lesson. She is the only reason that I gave "B" but not "A" for teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
I believe it is lenient.

Quiz 35% (cumulative and end-of-semester, basically a final exam but before the final period)
Marketing Plan (Group Project) 32%
Class participation 30%, consists of:
In-class participation 10% (the asking and answering meaningful questions thing)
2 topic essays of ~300 words 15% total
In-class activity 5% (a lesson was used for simple group classwork)
Research credit 3% (simply joining 3 research experiments from the MARK department outside class time to get this)
reviews.comment_workload:
No weekly assignments whatsoever.

The group project takes you the most time but I think there is enough time to deal with it. You think of a product or service to introduce in HKUST and apply the marketing concepts you learnt. There aren't many strict deadlines midway so it's up to your team to be hardworking or chill.

There are two 300-word essays and you try to apply concepts you learnt to real-life examples to show your understanding, so they are simple.

reviews.author: miche11e
reviews.title: Would love to retake
reviews.comment_content: You learn about the basics of marketing in this course - 4Ps and 3Cs. I personally love marketing so I looked forward to taking this course a lot and really did take away a lot of new knowledge. The content is pretty easy to understand, as long as you attend lectures and listen.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sophie is a super engaging professor whose passionate about marketing. I loved how she would show us ads during class and also give real life examples and actively ask us questions to get us thinking.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 2: 14 out of 25
Quiz 3: 17 out of 25
Final Project Presentation: 11 out of 15
Final Project Report: 17 out of 25
Group Exercise: 3 out of 5
Research Credit: 3 out of 3
Attendance and Participation could be +/- 10. I'm pretty sure I got the maximum 10/10 score added as my added grades were still pretty low for the absolute grading scheme.

Final Grade: B
I was initially aiming for an A in this course, but the quiz format has made it challenging to do so. Regardless, I think I got a fairly good grade since I got below mean for all my quizzes. It is VERY important to participate in this course. I participated at least once every lesson and attended every class so I think that played a big role in my grade.
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload is fair in this course. There's no midterm or final, but just three quizzes and a group project with report and presentation. Definitely manageable, but make sure you start everything early and double check your works.

reviews.author: Â•∂Ë∑ØËá£
reviews.comment_content:
Basically the same as others mention
1. 3C (Customers, Company and Competition)
2. STP (Segmentation, Targeting and Positioning)
3. 4P (Price, Product, Place and Promotion)

Simple and easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor has good preparation before classes and the materials are clear.

Make sure you raise your hands to answer questions if you want to earn participation credit as the time and questions are limited.
reviews.comment_grading:
Individual Tasks (58%):
Quizzes (The best 2 out of 3; 25% each)
Case Assignment 5%
Research Credit 3%

Group Project (42%):
Final Project Report 22%
Final Project Presentation 15%
Group Class Participation 5%

Bonus (10%):
Individual Class Participation 10%
reviews.comment_workload:
Preparation before class: Not necessary

Quizzes: Try to memorize the content in the lecture slides that the professor includes in the quiz review (Basically there will be a quiz review before every quiz, which includes the coverage and some sample questions)

Assignments: Two in total. Need to read around 10 pages of materials and answer around 3 to 4 questions for each assignment. Answer the professor's questions after group discussion during class (Pick one group representative)

Research credit: Just complete 3 sections and earn all the credits. It only takes you less than 1 hour for each section.

Group project: Make sure you have contributive groupmates and everything will be fine. To be honest, try to be the group leader if you want a good grade as you can realize it from the part of grading :)
But it is quite fun during the entire process of research, discussion and making the slides and written report

In conclusion, the workload for the individual tasks is not heavy while the workload for the group project fluctuates (it depends on the communication and work distribution within the group)

Anyway hope that you can get a good grade :)

reviews.author: procrastinator
reviews.title: genuinely the worst
reviews.comment_content: The content is relatively straightforward and simple, you can get a pretty good understanding from the presentation slides. There are also readings assigned for each topic (textbook chapters) but they're not necessarily required for your revision.
reviews.comment_teaching: I'm pretty neutral when it comes to how I feel about my professors, but Christine is genuinely the worst professor I have ever had. In order to force students to have to attend her lectures, she doesn't provide the lecture videos, and even though participation can affect your grade little to no people ever answer questions during lectures. Why? Because if you don't answer the way she wants or expects you to, she gives you shit in front of the whole class. Unlike my other group projects, she makes two people out of a team of six present, and then after the presentation, she gives her thoughts and criticism - and mind you this comes across as very harsh (especially if it's bad, and it likely will be). If you get her through pre-reg honestly just drop and try to get into another class because she is genuinely horrible.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1 (Midterm) 22% MCQ - 22/30 Mean 22.3
Quiz 2 (Final) 23% MCQ - 20/26 Mean 20.1
Group Project Report 25% - 88/100 Mean 75.3
Group Project Presentation 15% -  67/100 Mean 73.4
In-Class Exercises 12%
Research Participation 3% - 3/3
'EXTRA': Individual Class Participation +/- 10%

According to Christine's grading system an A- would be 89-91%, so basically the participation makes or breaks your A or A+. But again, Christine's manner when it comes to someone participating is harsh and unwarranted - so no one really wants to participate and answer questions during her lectures. In her eyes, it's either her way or no way. The biggest aspect of the grade percentage is the group project (this includes your in-class exercises). If you get a terrible team this basically will ruin your grade. I ended up with a B (because I never participated) and I had groupmates and I had to carry the project with another groupmate. For both the midterm and final you get an hour to do it but I finished both in less than 30 minutes (because they're both closed book).
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty heavy just because of the group project. It was honestly one of my hardest group projects to work on because my groupmates were terrible. Literally based purely on luck because the groups are assigned. If you get a shit group then good luck, not only do you have to carry the report, but you'll have to work on the ppt and do the presentation and end up getting shit on by Christine in front of the whole class because your group screwed their parts up (because that's what happened to me :) ) In terms of revising for the exams, you can just go over the lecture slides and be ok as long as you understand and remember everything (exams are closed book).

The workload is quite fair. There are 3 quizzes and a group project with a presentation. The quizzes are about the class content. The final group project has to use the concept from the lectures like
3C, STP, and 4P.

reviews.author: Tslaxx
reviews.comment_content: Okay. The course provides a basic but very well-structured framework of the marketing process, which is particularly useful not only for students aiming to be marketing professionals, but also anyone who wanna market himself when finding a job, selling his idea, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sophie is a very passionate professor. She values participation a lot.
reviews.comment_grading:

Quiz 3: 21/25 (mean: 19/25)

The grade of the group project was not released, but I think Sophie was satisfied with our work.

Also, if you want to get a higher grade, you should be active in the class. Trying to answer more questions in class.

My final grade: A-
I think the grading is good!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not very high. There are only three quizzes and one group project. If you pay attention to the class and jot notes well, the quizzes would not be so difficult for you.

reviews.author: solarski22
reviews.comment_content:
In total around 16 lectures with each of them lasting for 3 hours. The content are not too boring, at least better than those in mgmt2010 and 2130. Being a person who is not a big fan of business stuff, I think the content are still okay. This summer course could be hard if you are taking other courses at the same time, but if you are just taking this course in summer (3 credits), it is still manageable.

1. Course Introduction + What is the purpose of Marketing?
2. Managing Marketing Information + Consumer Markets and Consumer Buyer Behavior (Part A)
3. Consumer Markets and Consumer Buyer Behavior (Part B)
4. Marketing Strategy: Segmenting, Targeting & Positioning (STP) (Part A)
5. Marketing Strategy: Segmenting, Targeting & Positioning (STP) (Part B)
6. Marketing Strategy: Segmenting, Targeting & Positioning (STP) (Part C) + Product: Branding Strategy (Part A) (TBC) + Guest Lecture by Gabriela Simmons
7. Product: Branding Strategy (Part B)
8.  Pricing Concept: Understanding and Capturing Customer Value + Marketing Channels
9. The 4th P: Promotion (Part A)
10. The 4th P: Promotion (Part B) + Marketing Ethics and Social Responsibility
11. Guest Lecture by Kuo-Hi Lee
12. Marketing and Social Businesses: Gamechangers and Social
Entrepreneurs + In-class (group) activity
13. Product Development & Innovation
14. Brand Activism
15. Project presentation
16. Final Quiz

Suggestion: Read the textbook or slides by other professors earlier than her lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Puig is definitely a very kind person, she is very passionate and is very willing to talk to you either in class or after class. She is also responsive to emails and is very willing to provide assistance for you. It is doubtless that she is a good person to deal with, however, as this part is talking about teaching, I can only give a C-range to her (according to the ust grading way). The reason I do so is that she wasn't teaching too much, what she was doing is to blowwater and share her thoughts. She could stay on the same slide for an hour and just talking about her thoughts. I would say she will be very appropiate to teach MRKT on Youtube, but not in UST, in the latter case, you will definitely have to rely on the textbook and self-studying quite a lot to strike for a good grade. Putting teaching aside, she is nice, and of course, very humorous guy, so her lectures are not boring, but still, it is still a 9am class, so you better think twice before registering into it. She has some strong accents, but I think it is manageable. You can feel free to email her about any problems or random thoughts (e.g. MIRROR, yellow shopping circle in HK) about marketing you have, just make her remember you and to provide fedbacks to her teaching progress, which can help her a lot too.
reviews.comment_grading:
I know I am not the only one who hate MGMT, ISOM and MARK lectures which always encourage (force) students to speak up by adding a high proportion in participation. This course is not an exception. You can refer to my record if you are like me. I never spoke up in lectures. As long as you are not too weak in other components, you can still get B+ or above. (Getting C range in this course in summer is harder than that in ISOM2010)

Quiz 35%   [30/35 ; Max 33 ; mean 27 ; Min 22 ; revise is fine]
Marketing Plan (Group Project) 20%  [IDK]
Peer Evaluation 12%     [IDK]
Class Participation:
  - In-class participation 10%     [I typed less than 3 times on zoom]
  - 2 Topic essays of 200 words 15%    [full, easy, work hard here]
  - In-class Activity 5%            [full as long as you are there]
Physical Attendance in Class / Camera ON in Zoom 3%    [full]

There are a lot of god majors people in this course in summer, so becareful that the course is quite competitive. If you are like me, who just want to pass this course asap and avoid the bullshit pre-reg system in sbm, then it is still worth-taking. Make sure you find good groupmates, they can help you a lot in the project, do not be afraid of asking people whether you can join their group or not, if you come up with groups containing free-riders, you will be fucked up, so don't hesistate to find groupmates yourself, otherwise, the TA will help you do so and she might get you into some troubles if you are unlucky. If you are talkative and like speaking in class, this course suits you a lot. The prof will not force people to participate, but she really appreciate it if you could speak up, talking about sth wrong is okay, she will help you and will not make you embarrased. So think about it yourself~
reviews.comment_workload: It's a summer 9am course, 3 hrs each, 3 times a week. Considering only lecturing, it could already be quite tough. Nevertheless, there are still other components, like essays and the project. The essays are fine, not the challenging part. The project could be quite hard and hectic, but as mentioned, if you are just taking this course, it is still manageable. That's why I suggest you to read the textbook or slides by other professors (earlier than her lectures).  This could be helpful. But still, do not miss her lectures, she will give you some tips on the quizzes and they are not included in the textbooks!

reviews.author: PT
reviews.title: Grading is not as bad as people think, you just need to secure your participation marks
reviews.comment_content: Not gonna repeat previous reviews.  Imo, it is quite comprehensive where you get to learn a wide range of marketing concepts. A good course to get an overview of how mark is like.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Clear and not-too-bad accent
Interactive teaching style: He discusses real corporate cases to consolidate the theories, which is pretty authentic when it comes to well-known brands.
Slides are clear enough for self study but you are going to miss out the points from class discussion, which WILL appear in quizzes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Well this is controversial, but I don't think grading is that bad...just that participation matters - A LOT. You get up to a 10% bonus in your total score if you participate actively, and a max deduction of 10% if you disrupt the order in class (but I think no one will unless you forget to mute and said something bad lmao)

I got an average of 90/100 for the 3 quizzes (it only counts the best 2 btw). For the project I checked the ranking (yes you can email prof to check it), and our group didn't get the highest score. However I answered questions nearly every lecture actively and participated in the class discussions.

Got an A+ in the end.

My friend from the same project group with a slightly higher quiz score got a B, because he didn't participate that much (he did answer a few questions tho) - LOL
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload since there are only 3 quizzes with no mid terms nor finals. However it depends on the group project in the end - whether your group has free riders and how much time you are going to spend on it.

Attending all lectures is a must (for participation marks) unless you don't care about getting A range

reviews.author: stephyshum
reviews.comment_content: pretty much the same as above like 3C,STP,4P and other basic marketing concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall speaking, it's an interesting course. Sophie is also a very encouraging person that she really doesn't mind what your opinion is as long as you answer her and she always emphasizes there is participation mark. There are always many ppl raised their hands and answer her questions so don't be shy. She is helpful too as she replies to emails quite efficiently and willing to help you clear the concepts even if you give her any other situational cases other than those mentioned in lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Best two quizzes 25% each
Final Project Report 27%
Final project presentation 15%
Group Exercise 5%
Research credit 3%
Individual class participation +/-10%

Quiz1 Mean:16.1/25   Me:16
Quiz2 Mean:14.8/25   Me:16
Quiz3 Mean:17.6/25   Me:17
The mark for report, project and class participation were not released.
I think it pretty much depends on the group project and my group was just so-so that I guess it didn't score a mean mark so I end up getting a C+ haha....
P.S I tried to answer the questions once in every two lessons so I guess I would still have some participation mark but I don't think it affects much lol
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite fair since there are only three quizzes and choose the best two out of three and also a final project and report of presenting a new product or service consisting of the concept of 3C, STP, and 4P.

reviews.author: Guiltyghost
reviews.title: One of the best professors in UST, lucky if you are taught by Sophie!
reviews.comment_content:
3Cs, STP and 4Ps
Just some basic but useful marketing concepts, very easy to understand. But you should know how to apply those concepts in the real world. (really determines your grade).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sophie is a really nice and friendly professor! Her English is good (although has a bit accent), and she delivers concept in a very clear way (e.g. give some real-life examples). Some in-class exercises really help to understand the concept. There are also consultation sessions for you to ask questions about your group project, and she will give you detailed comments. Before each quiz, she will provide revision sessions (very important).
Personally, I think she is one of the best professors I have ever met in UST!
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Quizzes (Best 2)  25%
Final Project Report  27%
Final Project Presentation  15%
Group Exercise  5%
Research Credit  3%
Individual Class Participation +/-10%

The grading is pretty fair, Personally, I get an A (Best 2 quizzes: 18/25, 20/25; Score of group project not released).

It is easy to get full marks in research credit and group exercise. For the individual class participation, it is really important to attend and raise hand in every lecture so that Sophie will remember your name, and this counts a lot to your final grade.

Quizzes are not so difficult, they are all MC questions (will ask some questions about applying concepts in real world).
However, the options are quite ambiguous. Even after you finished the quizzes and check the notes, you will still not sure about your answer. As a result, no one get full marks in any of these quizzes. But if you pay attention in every lecture, you should have no problem with the quiz.
Since it is an online examination, it is close-book and pen is not allowed.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty low. There are no individual assignments. For the quizzes, if you pay attention in the lecture, it just cost you 1 day for revision (try to memorize all key concepts). The workload of group projects really depends on your teammate. But overall, the workload is still low for a 3 credit course.

reviews.author: Soberzz
reviews.title: Dilemma: GPA or Teaching style
reviews.comment_content:
Lots of marketing principles
4Ps
STP
Behaviours
Strategies
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching style generally fair
Quite enthusiastic and intriguing sometimes
But beware that he hides daggers in his smile.
And at the start and end of every semester he emphasises that he gives VERYVERYVERYVERYVERY good grade!!!
But don‚Äôt trust him, He gives out mostly C range.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading?
Some stats of my quiz scores
Quiz 1 95/100 (Mean 92.7)
Quiz 2 83/103 (Mean 88.1)
Quiz 3 90/100 (Mean 79.375, SD 12.07205)
Your best two quizzes contribute 50% scores of your grade
47% goes to your group works
i.e. mini-cases(useless, our group almost answered all common questions assigned for relevant groups, but he doesn‚Äôt give a shit on this, throw it, leave it, don‚Äôt waste too much time.), Presentation(he praises every group, comments is trash, he would kill your grade still.),
Final report(Zero comments are provided)
All these group works‚Äô score are NOT and WILL NOT be released. That is, you won‚Äôt know how he kills your grade.
3% for research credit(Should be all full)
And lastly, the big boss
10% BONUS PARTICIPATION(Which you have to compete with others for a chance to speak. He only counts how many times you speak, NOT how many lectures you attend, bear in mind)
If you are those who are not willing to speak up, don‚Äôt ever reg him. It just ruins your grade.
Overall, a 0.9 SD above avg in one quiz, still drags me to C range. Surprise!
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload?
After your grade is released, you will find out that all your efforts are useless, both group and individual. I won‚Äôt say the workload is heavy, but really makes you frustrated when you realise all your hard work is actually nothing, nothing at all.

reviews.author: bob131
reviews.title: Mark 2120 Christine Kim
reviews.comment_content: Content is super straight forward, you either know it or you don't. All the content you need to know is all in the slides which she doesn't usually share because you'll realize she isn't teaching anything.
reviews.comment_teaching: She treats the entire class like 10 year olds, on occasion she's scolded people for asking questions but on other days gets mad if no one raises their hand. Her teaching is basically reading off her slides which is why she doesn't share them.
reviews.comment_grading: Her grading is super skewed and subjective because its absolute grading despite having short essay style questions in the quizzes. Getting mean for everything would be around a C+.
reviews.comment_workload: Depends on your group

reviews.author: lamok
reviews.title: Inspiring and Unforgettable Summer
reviews.comment_content:
The content about marketing in the textbook was 'obsolete' so we have new 'update' every class.
Talking about Maslow' pyramid, how it relates to consumer needs. [The pyramid is like very old and famous theory, but in this class you will learn why and how it woks.] Prof. Puig have a different version of these needs and relevant product categories according to her marketing experience.
Also the consumer wants. blablabla
And the 4P, the 'update' is SAFE (use SAFE during your project is a good idea)
Many other things covered are not in the textbook but are life lessons.
e.g. Lectures about the political propaganda and the responsible marketing of fast fashion are very insightful. You can understand marketing from a different perspective.
There are some guest lectures, you can attend according to your own interest. It's always good to know more but if you don't want to it's still fine.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very inspiring content provided for each class.
She is the most inspired person I ever met. I wasn't treated like her kids {like Carrie Lam lol} but she never hesitated to provide insights of life to us.
Prof. Puig also tried her best to make this class interesting and enjoyable. I love the TED talk she shared and the advertisements she played during the class. The comments and reflections of these videos helped me undertand and reflect a lot about life and of course marketing.
Experienced expert in the field of marketing.
I had attended her sharing to other mannagers of big companys before taking this course(Also the reason why I chose this course).
She always talked about her accent and sometimes couldn't pronounce 'that word' but I think it's fun and cute haha.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think PARTICIPATION is SUPER IMPORTANT, since Prof tried to remember each student's name. Try to speak up every class. This is more like the impression mark and is quite fair for a small class.

The presentation is also important and easy, just follow the project guidelines and make sure you have nice groupmates. (I have very nice groupmates :) )

To study for final quiz, you can check the last slides of the powerpoint which highlighted the main idea for each class.
Don't worry if you attend all lecture and be punctual. Prof would tell these students what would be the main questions in exam and what pages of textbook are important. And the quiz is very easy if you attend the leacture.

Amazing grading.

I think quite a number of students are in A range since Prof. Puig don't care about the curving during summer semester. She think if you deserve an A then you should have it.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only one group project and final presentation.
Go to class [was 9am in LSK for us] is not a workload, it's the responsiblity for yourself. [Don't take this course if you cannot attend the class]
The reading material is for students who do not dare to speak up in class. You can get half of the participation mark if you do all the commentary.

reviews.author: Wendyyy
reviews.comment_content:
3C---customer, company, competitor
STP---segmentation, targeting, positioning
4P---place, price, promotion, product
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very restrictive class rules: no phones and laptops, tablets are allowed only for notes taking, must bring name cards every time.
Good points about her classes:
She teaches well, provides many examples to explain concepts and remember her students' names.
Not many lectures actually, since there won't be class on every quiz date and last few lectures are presentations.
Quizzes have light content.

Potential challenges in her class:
No clear instructions on how to do the project (introduce an existing product to Hong Kong market)
Getting high scores in quizzes need a bit of luck.
Strong group mates are important, better take the course with friends
May feel a bit bored in class since you are not allowed to talk for most of the time and you can't use your phone.

I would recommend taking her class if you have good discipline and is interested in marketing basics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes (2 of 3) 27% each
Project: Report 20% Presentation 13%
In-class exercises 10%
Research participation 3%
Parti +-10%

Quiz 1         March 5 (24.5/27 mean 20.2)
Quiz 2        March 28, evening  (21/27 mean 18.1)
Quiz 3        April 25, evening (20.6/27 mean 18.1)
Final Project Presentations
April 30, May 2 and 7
Final Project Report Due    
May 14

I got A although I have only spoken in class once. Finishing strong in the project is not enough to secure A range, after reading other reviews, I think getting high scores in quizzes is crucial, which is reasonable since they worth 54% of the grade total.
reviews.comment_workload: Not high except having to go for market research and doing the project. The workload is heavy before the presentation, when most of the project report should have been completed. Two people in the group have to prepare for a 12mins presentation with Q&A.

reviews.author: little potatoo
reviews.comment_content:
This course is designed to provide students with sufficient knowledge of marketing principles that will enable them to understand the role and operation of a marketing manager. It will also help them develop skills necessary to analyze marketing problems leading to the development of strategic and tactical plans consistent with analysis.
On a broad level, students in this course are expected to be able to:
1. Explain and discuss the general concepts about marketing management and the marketing process.
2. Identify and explain the key elements of a marketing plan.
3. Conduct a thorough analysis of the marketing environment and identify the marketing
problems facing a company.
4. Identify sources of marketing information necessary to develop a marketing plan.
5. Discuss consumer and buyer behavior models as they influence customer purchase
decision‚Äêmaking.
6. Explain the concepts of segmentation, targeting and positioning as part of a
comprehensive marketing plan.
7. Describe product, price, distribution, and promotion decisions as part of a marketing
strategy and plan.
8. Identify and explain key issues surrounding marketing ethics and social responsibility.
9. Develop a set of skills important to successful performance in marketing management
positions, including critical thinking, working in a group environment, oral and written presentation skills.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is funny and he likes participation very much. He would call on you if you play phone or chat during the lesson, so pls be very focus to wt he says. Also, attendance is counted EVERY LESSON! and you need to sign your name on his attendance sheet so you literally can't skip any lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
fair grading I would say.
three quizzes in total, but only count for the two best.
one group project.
no final
reviews.comment_workload: just need to study for quizzes

reviews.author: Tayloryoyoyoyo
reviews.title: Quite fun learning atmosphere, but hard to understand
reviews.comment_content: The content of her powerpoint and the textbook is normal and comprehensive, but not quite consistent to what she taught in class. The experience of herself shared in class are highly irrelevant to what were tested in quizzes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching style is casual and engaging, she threw lots of questions for discussion and instant answer. She also provided several case analysis for in-class discussion. REALLY HARD TO FOLLOW HER ACCENT!!!!
reviews.comment_grading: Fair. Because the grade highly depends on the performance of projects, it is extremely possible to get a satisfactory grade if you participate proactively in class and make her remember you.
reviews.comment_workload: Relatively low compare to other business courses. Given no mid term, final. And not much course materials to prepare as well as essay to write.

reviews.author: kycc
reviews.title: hell for introverts
reviews.comment_content:
mainly follow textbook
consumers' behaviour
marketing strategies
marketing process
reviews.comment_teaching: Her Columbian accent is somehow hard to understand. Her teaching was interesting though. She shared lots of her experience in marketing and sometimes her personal life including marriage etc.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes is 40% but actually grading is positively related to how much you speak up in the lessons. It doesn't depend on how hard you study.
Around mean for every quiz, but did not speak much. So I got C.

Quizzes: 40%
Marketing plan: 25.9%
Peer evaluation: 11.1%
In-class activities: 20%
Marketing experiment: 3%
reviews.comment_workload: No homework. Just one group project. 3 quizzes. Around one per month.

reviews.author: minnieyim
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly an introductory course in marketing. It will teach you how to make a marketing plan. Basically, you will know  how to do an analysis of consumer tension,3Cs, STP, 4Ps.
I think the topic about societal marketing is the most interesting and useful even if you are not a marketing-major student.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor actually delivers very interesting classes. She is very open to opinions from students and she is funny. Make sure you pay attention in class and make an impression. She mentions some of the most important things in lectures which you cannot find in textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes 50% (Individual)
Case Analysis 17% (Team)
Marketing Plan 20% (Team)
In-class activities 10% (Team/Individual)
Marketing Experiment 3% (Individual)

Professor counts all three quizzes in your final grade so you cannot give up on any one of them. The overall average (in my class anyway) is insanely high.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy because it has frequent quizzes and you really need to revise the textbook for those.
The case analysis is relatively easy, just write about marketing strategy and comment on it (for me, it is the Beyonce business case).
The marketing plan requires more time and effort. But if you make good use of the in-class time that professor gave you to discuss and work it should be fine.

Again, this course will require some of your spare time to get the three credits of marketing experiments.

reviews.author: yyyw
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1: Three C's
- Company
- Customer
- Competitor
Part 2: STP
- Segmentation
- Targeting
- Positioning
- Branding
Part 3: Four P's
- Product
- Price
- Place
- Promotion
reviews.comment_teaching:
need to sit with group mates following the seating plan
provides many examples
not only teach according to the ppts
midterms may contain questions asking what examples are used to illustrate a specific concept
don't skip the examples during revision
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 50% (25% each, only the best two out of three quizzes will be considered)
Final Project Report 15%
Final Project Presentation Presentation 7%
Marketing Puzzle 10% + presentation 5%
Group Exercise 10%
Research credit 3%
Individual Class Presentation +/-10%
quiz 1: 88/100 (mean: 84.4)
quiz 2: 92/100 (mean: 76.3)
quiz 3: 92/100 (mean: 75.3)
marketing puzzle: 10/10
got a B at last
reviews.comment_workload:
extremely heavy workload
need to work as a team for most of the time
6-7 students per group, groups are formed by ourselves
group project matters a lot
3 group exercise (case study) - need to prepare for the questions and answer during the classes, marks will only be given for answering the questions, no paper will be collected
marketing puzzle is a project about the strange phenomenon in the market, the marketing puzzle report followed a presentation
Other than the marketing puzzle, there's still a final report
the final report is very time-consuming and annoying
It already toke up a lot of time for choosing the topic (product)
Be careful when choosing group mates, 3 of my group mates are free-rider and therefore it really toke a lot of time for us to finish the work

reviews.title: I think it was good
reviews.comment_content:
Never learned Marketing or what so ever, but it wasn't difficult to understand. Just some basic concepts. However, the course isnt just about understanding. it is also about how you are able to put it into use.
Part 1: Three C's
- Company
- Customer
- Competitor
Part 2: STP
- Segmentation
- Targeting
- Positioning
- Branding
Part 3: Four P's
- Product
- Price
- Place
- Promotion
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was interesting. Wasn't hard to follow. He's not the type of professors that just reads off ppt. He has a lot of interaction with students. He uses a lot of case studies to help students comprehend the course concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: Honestly, He doesn't give very good grades. Even though he tells you that his grading is not so different from other professors but dont trust him. Period.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was not so heavy except for the final project. especially when I had to do 80% of it and present alone. The final project needs you to think of a new product idea or an existing product and introduce it to the class. it would be a 15 mins presentation.

reviews.author: Vivain
reviews.comment_content: Basic stuff about marketing, great introductory course if you want to know more about marketing (as major)
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor was humorous and used a lot of real life examples in the teaching. Did not allow any computers or phones during lecture though.
reviews.comment_grading: Group project matters a lot, as the quizzes are super easy and everyone's gonna do great on them
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy work load, mostly presentation and quizzes
Case study, assignment and project all done as a group, and he let you form your group, so it's important to group responsible groupmates.

reviews.author: vickie_135
reviews.comment_content: Easy concepts, an interesting group projects -- a sales pitch. A few case studies. Basically learning stuff in lectures and applying it in practical situations.
reviews.comment_teaching: People warned me about her for some reason but she's actually quite OK? She's a bit 'high school' as in she'll tell you off for talking too much but other than that she's cool.
reviews.comment_grading: I was above mean in all my assessment but only a little bit but I still got an A+. Love you Amy.
reviews.comment_workload:
Amy doesn't make you read the whole chapter of the textbook so you'll be more familiar with less things which I think is really good.
There are group projects. DO NOT group with local ex-co members... had to learn that lesson the hard way. Grouping with fun friends and the projects will seem less like a chore. Not a lot of workload if everyone contributes.
I'm not great at presenting so it was a bit of a hassle when Amy forces you to not have cue cards in the presentations. However, its better than LABU. Practice you parts well or look bad in front of the whole class.

reviews.author: Anonymous18
reviews.comment_content:
Marketing Process
Company and marketing strategy
Assessing (Global) Marketing Environment
Understanding Consumer behaviour
Managing Marketing Information (Market research)
STP
Segmentation, Targeting, & Positioning
4 P's
Product
Pricing and Place
Promotion

The content is not difficult to understand (concepts and examples related to daily life). There are few basic calculations for pricing.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sophie is an enthusiastic and interactive professor. She used lot of brands liked by the class. She also incorporated feedback of students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Best 2 Quizzes out of 3 (individual work)            25% each
Final Project Report (group work)            27%
Final Project Presentation (group work)        15%
Group Exercise (group work)                5%
Research Credit (individual work)            3%                                                                            Individual Class Participation (individual work)    +/- 10%

The quizzes have multiple choice questions, which makes it a little challenging.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is like an average business school course. The quizzes can be prepared in a few days. The project can take time, depending on product chosen.

reviews.author: kazsyrup
reviews.title: Fun and Engaging Summer course
reviews.comment_content: It's a lot of content jammed into four weeks of class so a lot of knowledge is briefly touched but never discussed furter, so if you are a business major do not take it in the summer, but for us wh just have it as arequred course, it is very much enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: I love Professor Coral, she made me feel seen and heard in class. Despite all classes being 9am and four hours long, I never felt bored or sleepy. She makes everything engaging and gripping, a lot of in class discussions and interaction, whih is perfect for active learners.
reviews.comment_grading: As long as you try and work hard enought the grading will not be bad. But key word is that you need to communicate with your grou mates and actively contribute or the peer evaluation will fuck you up badly.
reviews.comment_workload: No work except for a 300 word essay and a group project

reviews.author: sy226
reviews.comment_content:
3Cs (consumer, company, competitor analysis)

STP (segmentation, targeting, positioning)

4Ps (product, price, place, promotion: in this specific order)
*The above 3 are literally the most important things you will need in your project

Some other topics in class included branding, consumer buyer behavior, customer value, and ethics. It's quite standard for a foundational marketing course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Coral is a very passionate teacher, and her classes are actually very interesting. She includes a lot of her own experiences and examples in her presentations, and she likes to repeat important concepts a lot in all of her lectures to make sure we remember. And it works quite well. The only thing is her accent: it is so heavy. So unless you are able to understand her Spanish accent, you will not have a good time (or good grade) in her class.
reviews.comment_grading: Coral's grading is very lenient, but it also depends a lot on whether she knows you exist. Attendance is not mandatory in her class, but your chances at getting a good final grade will increase greatly if she knows you on a first name basis. If you succeed in getting her to remember you, you will not only have a more favorable impression, she will call on you more in class so you get more chances to get participation points. So just attend and participate more in class. It really helps.
reviews.comment_workload: Coral doesn't assign any (mandatory) weekly or daily homework, so it's relatively chill (but the readings she puts on the syllabus are definitely helpful if you're interested in marketing and want to do well on the final exam). There are 2 short essays that need to be completed at some point throughout the semester, but as long as the topic is related to class content and your use of technical terms is correct, you're pretty much guaranteed to get full marks on those. The only things that need more effort required is the group project and the final exam.

reviews.author: APKB
reviews.title: Better than Expactations
reviews.comment_content: Essential knowledge that is crucial for all business students.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nice professors, good powerpoint, great motivator during lecutres.
reviews.comment_grading: All quizzes lie on UQ, quite high mark in project -> A. Was absent for one lecture without telling the professor, answered question in about 70% of lecutures.
reviews.comment_workload: Many book chapters to read if you want to get a high mark in the quizzes as some content that does not mention in PPT but in textbook are covered in quiz. 3 groupwork in whole semesters, which takes you several hours each. Final project is fun but quite time-consuming as you need to write a marketing plan and do a presentation to sell a product or service to investors.

reviews.author: clyak
reviews.comment_content:
3Cs, 4Ps, STP (including ethics).
Stuff that you‚Äôve learnt in secondary school already.
It‚Äôs easy to understand.
Just make sure to find responsible teammates as the marketing plan takes up 25% of the total course grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: Amy prepares lecture slides before lessons and her accent is clear and nice to follow up. She is willing to answer your questions and provides opportunities for students to get class participation by prioritising those who seldom raise their hand.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 23%@ (Best 2 out of 3)
Case Analysis 6%
Marketing Plan 25%
Class Participation 10%
In-class Activities 10%
Academic Research 3%

My Statistics for reference:
Quiz 1 20/25 (mean 16.9)
Quiz 2 20/24 (mean 18.2)
Quiz 3 18/22 (mean 17.0)
Case Analysis 5/6 (mean 5.0)
Marketing Plan 20.5/25 (mean 22.0, our group is in the low quartile)
Class Participation 7/10 (mean 3.8)
In-Class Activities 10/10
Academic Research 3/2

Grade: A-

Conclusion: just try to get participation scores if you can. Cuz you see, even if I score low at the marketing plan and just got above mean in the quizzes, I can still get A-range, most probably is because I have class participations :D
Some simple questions like ‚Äúis this secondary or primary data‚Äù counts towards class participation, and I guess wrong answers also count towards it lol. Just don‚Äôt be shy and try to speak up will be fine.
reviews.comment_workload:
Can say that the workload is low to little if you get good teammates for the marketing plan. No need to be too formal for the presentation, the dress code seems more to be like business casual than business formal.
If you already score high enough in the first 2 quizzes, you can skip the third one directly. Just read through the PowerPoint is enough to get 80% correct but if you wish to score higher, remember to go through the textbook as well.
All in class activities are really done in class so you got to be quick or else you cannot finish them on time.
Just be a lab rat and do some kind of survey 3 times you get secure the 3% for academic research. Even if you forgot to register, the marketing department will send a link later that you can do the survey online, so no worries if you missed some research sessions.

reviews.author: Ovaltine
reviews.title: One of the best professors in UST
reviews.comment_content:
The content covers basic marketing principles and is structured very well.  The whole course follows the marketing process that ultimately builds up to a final group project where students have to pitch a new business idea to the class.

Marketing process:
3Cs
STP + ethics
4Ps

Overall the content is very interesting and provides students with basic knowledge of marketing concepts and most importantly students get a chance to put what is learnt to practice.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Amy is one of the best professors in HKUST as seen in other reviews and good relationships she has between students.  During class she will encourage students to participate in class discussion and will try to assist or direct them in the right direction if students are unsure.  Her teaching is very clear and engaging to all students whether they are business students or not.  
Her power points are simple and clearly shows important concepts and ideas to study for.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for this course is very reasonable and consists of:

Individual:
Best 2 out of 3 quizzes (23% each)
Just know the concepts well and understand how they apply to examples, also make sure you read assigned chapters

Participation (10%)
Raise your hand up to answer her questions and the TA will note down your participation, try to do it once per class

Academic research (3%)
Become UST lab rats and do 3 consumer behavior tests in LSK, takes around 30-60 min

Group work
Case analysis (6%) + In class activities (10%)
Case analysis and in class activity is just where groups will write a response together to some questions or analysis of a case study

Marketing plan (25%)
The biggest part of the course where groups will have to write a marketing report and presentation for the class on their own business idea and how they will market it to the public.
Application of everything that is learnt in class.

My grades:
Quizzes: 23/25 + 21/22  > mean around 17

Case analysis: 5/6 > mean is 5.05

In class activities:
3/3 + 19/20 + 5.5/6 > marks is around mean

Participation
10/10 > mean is 3.79

Academic research 3/3

Overall A+
(Case analysis and marketing plan have peer evaluation)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload in this course is not bad, but it can be overwhelming to have 3 quizzes and the marketing presentation.  Individual studying isn't too bad but workload really depends on group members.  If your group is bad then be prepared to stay up at LC all night.

reviews.comment_content:
3C (customer, company, competitor)
STP (segmentation, targeting, positioning)
4Ps (price, place, promotion, product)
case study x 2

The content is easy to understand, just remember the concept and don't need much calculation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is nice and friendly. She teaches the concept clearly, and clear accent to listen.
She gives many opportunities to students to get the participation marks, like inviting some less raise their hands.
reviews.comment_grading:

- Project Present 15%
- Group participation 5%

I didn't get much parti and didn't go to the research sections. Best 2 quizzes above the upper quartile, finally a B. I think that's fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy as the content is simple to understand and don't need much effort. You can get high mark in the quizzes as long as you put effort on it. No mid-term and final. Just 3 quizzes.

For the 2 case assgmt, I remember just answer 3-4 questions using concept learned in class.

Workload for group project depends on your groupmates (you can choose 1 friend in same group and others are random), my group work well the workload is appropriate.

other marketing strategy

Case studies: the 2 case studies are quite long but you can find relevant answers on the internet as references

-Expected an A- but got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
very low workload, 4 quizzes, 2 case studies, and one project.

Case studies: the 2 case studies are quite long but you can find relevant answers on the internet as references
